data.question: What are the two nitro-containing imidazolate ligands used to construct the NOF frameworks?
data.answer: The two nitro-containing imidazolate ligands used are 2-nitroimidazole (2nIm) and 5-methyl-4-nitroimidazole (mnIm).

data.question: How were the single crystals of NOF-1 prepared?
data.answer: Single crystals of NOF-1 were prepared by dissolving 2-nIm and Zn(NO3)2路6H2O in DMF and heating the solution to 100掳C via microwave irradiation for 1 hour. The yield could be increased by further heating in a 100掳C oven for 24 hours.

data.question: What is the key difference between the crystal structures of NOF-1 and NOF-2?
data.answer: NOF-1 crystallizes in a cubic crystal system, creating a perfectly truncated octahedral sodalite cage, whereas NOF-2 crystallizes in a trigonal crystal system, exhibiting an elongated sodalite cage along the c axis.

data.question: Why did the cobalt analogue [Co(2nIm)2]n fail to release significant quantities of NO compared to the zinc-based NOF-1?
data.answer: The cobalt center in [Co(2nIm)2]n has low-energy ligand field states that can deactivate the excited states localized on the nitro-functionalized ligands, disfavoring the photochemical NO release pathway. This highlights the importance of the choice of metal ion in constructing efficient photoactive frameworks.

data.question: What is the proposed advantage of assembling NO photodonors into porous coordination polymer structures compared to using them directly?
data.answer: Assembling NO photodonors into porous coordination polymer structures provides spatial segregation between the donors, preventing aggregation-induced quenching of reactive excited states. This leads to a drastic increase in photoreactivity compared to using the photodonor ligands directly.

data.question: How were the NOF-1 microcrystals immobilized to create a cell stimulation platform?
data.answer: The NOF-1 microcrystals were spin-cast onto a glass-bottomed culture dish and then embedded in a polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) layer by spin-coating a pre-polymer/curing agent mixture. This created a biocompatible substrate with the crystals localized on the bottom part.

data.question: What technique was used to achieve precise and localized photoactivation of the NOF-1/PDMS substrates for NO delivery to cells?
data.answer: Near-infrared two-photon laser scanning confocal microscopy was used to precisely photoactivate selected regions containing NOF-1 crystals. This allowed for localized NO delivery to the surrounding cells with high spatiotemporal resolution.

data.question: True or False: The NOF-1 microcrystals embedded in the PDMS substrate induced significant cytotoxicity in the cultured HEK293 cells compared to pristine PDMS.
data.answer: False. Compared to pristine PDMS substrates, the presence of NOF-1 in the polymer layer did not induce any notable cytotoxicity in the HEK293 cells.

data.question: True or False: The biological relevance of the NO released from photoactivated NOF-1 was demonstrated by observing an increase in intracellular calcium levels mediated by an NO-sensitive membrane protein.
data.answer: True. The NO released from photoactivated NOF-1 reacted with the NO-sensitive TRPC5 ion channel in modified HEK293-TRPC5 cells, triggering its opening and leading to an influx of calcium ions and transient increase in intracellular calcium concentration.

data.question: True or False: Irradiation of the control [Zn(MeIm)2]n crystals, which lack nitro groups, was able to induce an intracellular fluorescence increase in DAF-FM loaded cells.
data.answer: False. Irradiation of the [Zn(MeIm)2]n crystals under identical photoactivation conditions did not induce any increase in intracellular DAF-FM fluorescence, confirming the role of the nitro groups in NO release.

data.question: What is the chemical formula of NOF-1?
data.answer: The chemical formula of NOF-1 is Zn(2nIm)2 or C6H4N6O4Zn.

data.question: What is the topology of the porous coordination frameworks formed by NOF-1 and NOF-2?
data.answer: Both NOF-1 and NOF-2 form 3D porous coordination frameworks with sodalite (sod) topology.

data.question: How many nitro functionalities are exposed in each sodalite cage of NOF-1 and NOF-2?
data.answer: Twelve nitro functionalities are exposed in each sodalite cage of NOF-1 and NOF-2 without significant interaction with neighboring atoms.

data.question: What percentage of nitro groups were converted to NO after 3 hours of light irradiation for NOF-1 and NOF-2?
data.answer: After 3 hours of light irradiation, the conversion yield of nitro groups to NO was 50% for NOF-1 and 46% for NOF-2.

data.question: Why does NOF-1 exhibit a moderately superior NO-releasing efficiency compared to NOF-2 under 300-600 nm light irradiation?
data.answer: NOF-1 has better light absorption capacity in the 400-500 nm range compared to NOF-2 due to the nitro substitution position on the imidazole ring. This allows NOF-1 to more efficiently absorb light and release NO.

data.question: What gas analysis technique confirmed that NO was the only nitrogen oxide species released upon irradiation of NOF-1?
data.answer: Gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) analysis confirmed that NO was the only nitrogen oxide species released after the irradiation of NOF-1, with no detection of NO2 or N2O4.

data.question: How does the NO release from NOF-1 compare to the non-porous framework NOF-3 under the same irradiation conditions?
data.answer: The amount of NO released from the non-porous NOF-3 (1.2 渭mol/mg after 3 hours) was significantly reduced compared to the porous NOF-1 under the same irradiation conditions. This supports the design strategy of achieving efficient NO release by constructing porous frameworks from NO photodonor building blocks.

data.question: True or False: The NO release from NOF powders can be instantly initiated by light irradiation and quickly terminated when the irradiation ceases.
data.answer: True. NO is released instantly upon photoactivation of NOF powders and the production is immediately interrupted when the irradiation ceases, with NO concentration quickly dropping to trace levels.

data.question: True or False: Heating NOF powders up to 200掳C resulted in significant NO release.
data.answer: False. Heating NOF powders up to 200掳C did not result in significant NO release, confirming their thermal stability and that NO is produced exclusively through a photochemical process.

data.question: What fluorescent calcium indicator was used to monitor intracellular calcium concentration changes in the HEK293 and HEK293-TRPC5 cells?
data.answer: Fluo-4 was used as the fluorescent calcium indicator to monitor intracellular calcium concentration changes in the HEK293 and HEK293-TRPC5 cells after photoactivation of NOF-1.

data.question: What conformational change occurs in the TRPC5 ion channel upon reaction with the NO released from photoactivated NOF-1?
data.answer: The NO released from photoactivated NOF-1 reacts with the TRPC5 ion channel, causing it to undergo a conformational change that opens the channel and allows an influx of extracellular calcium ions into the cell.
